name: Creeping Moss
resist: cold, fire, poison; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from non-magical weapons
immunity: blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, prone
senses: blindsight 60 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 8

effect.text: When the moss takes cold, fire, or poison damage, it shrinks one size smaller. The moss can become no smaller than Tiny.
The moss regains 10 hit points at the start of its turn, growing one size larger in the process. The moss can be no larger than Gargantuan, but can still regain hit points.
While the moss remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a large patch of moss.
The moss can occupy another creature's space and vice versa, and the moss can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.
The space the moss occupies is considered difficult terrain. A creature that starts its turn in the moss' space takes 3 (
to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.
) poison damage and the target is grappled (escape
) and pulled 5 feet into the moss' space. Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained.
The moss makes a pseudopod attack against a creature that moves within 5 feet of it, or within its space.

info.name: Found Among the Dead.
desc: The death of animate plant life has unintended effects on that which feasts upon its decay. Creeping moss forms wherever flora used to thrive. The lichen and fungi that consume the compost left from magical living plants gain an intrinsic sentience of their own, as well as a ravenous appetite for living flesh.

info.name: Carnivorous Lichen.
desc: Though most commonly found in dying forests and bogs, creeping moss can be a hidden hazard for any cave delver. It has a hunger that is never sated, no matter the size of its prey. Creeping moss is usually opportunistic in its approach by letting its food come to it, but occasionally it will go out of its way to hunt, moving to a new location if it has depleted its own resources. Behind it leaves a trail of desolation as no life escapes its slow but unyielding digestion.

info.name: Combat.
desc: Creeping moss is strongest when adventurers have already moved over the top of it, walking on its lush surface without realizing the horror beneath. Without this element of surprise, the moss is a relatively weak enemy, despite its regenerative properties. Its action and reaction are meant to keep enemies rooted while they are slowly poisoned to death by its underfoot trait. All the while, it grows in size, making escape that much harder.

name: Igamon
vuln: Damage from silvered or magical weapons

effect.text: The igamon is immune to the effects of all spellcasting. When hit by or subject to the effects of a spell being cast, the igamon ignores the effects and damage. If the spell normally deals damage, the igamon instead gains temporary hit points equal to the spell's level in
temporary hit points for damaging cantrips.
If the igamon ever has 15 or more temporary hit points, it reverts to its true form, keeping its temporary hit points. When reverting this way, all creatures within 5ft of the igamon must make a
force damage and be pushed back 5ft.
The igamon makes two Arcane Slam attacks.

) bludgeoning damage. On a hit, the igamon can choose to sacrifice any amount of its temporary hit points. The target takes the same amount of temporary hit points lost as additional force damage.

The igamon magically assumes the shape of a Small or Medium humanoid or beast with a challenge rating of 1 or less that it has seen. It uses the same rules as a druid's Wild Shape ability, but can use its arcane slam attacks. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies, or if it dismisses this effect as an action.

info.desc: An igamon is said to be a doppelganger that has forgotten its true form. They live in an existence beyond the weave, eating at its edges in hopes to return to a mortal existence.

The bubbler does not need to remain within reach to continue grappling. Additionally, the bubbler can grapple any number of creatures.
As a bonus action, the bubbler forces all creatures that are currently grappled by it to make a
Strength saving throw or hover 10 ft. upwards.
While the bubbler remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a fizzing pool of acid or poison.

info.desc: Sometimes the result of a foul potion or a witches brew gone awry, bubblers float amidst caustic pools awaiting prey to digest. Once close, the bubbler strikes and envelops its meal. It then floats it away before dropping it to the ground to become an easily digestible puddle of flesh.

name: Giant's Hand
senses: tremorsense 30 ft. (blind beyond this radius), passive Perception 10

effect.text: If the hand falls 5 ft. or more upon a target, the hand can make a slam attack at the target as a bonus action. If the attack hits, the target falls prone.
The hand can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

The hand has advantage on Strength checks made to grapple. The hand can only grapple one target at a time, and cannot move or use its slam attack while grappling. A target that starts its turn grappled by the hand takes 8 (
to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.

info.desc:
Crawling claws are the severed hands of murderers animated by dark magic so that they can go on killing. Wizards and warlocks of a dark bent use crawling claws as extra hands in their labors.

### Gigantic Origins
Much larger than crawling claws, a giant's hand isn't as nimble as its counterpart, but many times stronger.

info.desc: Cyprins are originally from the river Oceanus within the plane of Elysium, but swim and wander across the planes through its many waterways. They seek to do good deeds, and bless aquatic travelers on their journeys. Though cyprins can float, they cannot breathe air. Therefore, they prefer to stay below the surface. When forced above, they will carry with them a large droplet of water surrounding their body in order to breathe.

Strength saving throw or become entangled in natural growth, causing them to be restrained for 1 minute. A creature can use their action to repeat the saving throw on its turn, ending the effect on itself on a success.
The treegon can also choose any number of willing creatures within the cone to gain

The treegon magically animates one or two trees it can see within 60 feet of it. These trees have the same statistics as an

The tree remains animate for 1 day or until it dies; until the treegon dies or is more than 120 feet from the tree; or until the treegon takes a bonus action to turn it back into an inanimate tree. The tree then takes root if possible.

Dexterity saving throw. On a success, the creature is shunted back above ground. On a failure, the earth around the creature refills and they are restrained. A creature shorter than 5 ft. cannot speak or breathe while restrained in this way.

If the earth around the creature can be moved by hand, it takes an action to dig the creature out and free them. If the earth around the creature is solid and cannot be easily moved, then a hammer, pick, or mason's tools must be used as an action by an unrestrained creature to free the restrained creature.

The propulsor's speed is not reduced while grappling or being grappled.

A creature within 5 feet of the gel can take an action to pull a creature or object out of the gel. Doing so requires a successful
The gel can hold only one Medium creature or up to four smaller creatures inside it at a time.
While moving, the gel can enter Medium or smaller creatures' spaces. Whenever the gel enters a creature's space, the creature must make a
On a successful save, the creature can choose to be pushed 5 feet back or to the side of the gel. A creature that chooses not to be pushed suffers the consequences of a failed saving throw.
On a failed save, the gel enters the creature's space and the creature is engulfed. The engulfed creature begins suffocating with no chance to hold their breath and is stunned, but gains 2 (

A stunned creature can try to escape by making a

The golem has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.
The golem's weapon attacks are magical.
The golem makes two shock punch attacks.

info.desc:
The long-forgotten constructs of Gemfathom continue to execute their designated tasks endlessly. Danger persists within the mines, but no invention inspires as much fear in would-be adventurers as the Lightning Golem.

Built to defend the tunnels from the threat of deep dwelling evils, the golems were soldiers, artillery, and transit all in one. The howdah on their back was meant as a means of escape and protection for fleeing dwarves. Their powerful arms would shock any monster into submission, while the beam that shot from their chest could melt through stone.

Now abandoned, the golems have difficulty pinpointing friend from foe due to a lack of circuitry maintanence. Some creatures the golem was built to destroy have now inhabited the fortress carried on their back, turning them back into nigh-unstoppable war machines.

senses: blindsight 10 ft., darkvision 60 ft., passive Perception 11

The voltant magically teleports, along with any equipment it is carrying, up to 40 ft. to an unoccupied space it can see. Before or after teleporting, the voltant can make one bite attack.

info.desc: Voltants are the light of the underdark. They swarm into spherical hive colonies that hang from vast ceilings, like bright shining moons in an underground night.

effect.text: If a creature starts its turn within 30 feet of the basilisk and the two of them can see each other, the basilisk can force the creature to make a

Constitution saving throw if the basilisk isn't incapacitated. On a successful save, the creature magically becomes lethargic and takes one level of exhaustion. On a failed save, the creature magically becomes fatigued and takes two levels of exhaustion.

A creature that isn't surprised can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If it does so, it can't see the basilisk until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If it looks at the basilisk in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.
Two levels of the basilisk's exhaustion are lifted on a short rest, and all are lifted on a long rest, so long as the basilisk that caused the effects has been slain.
If the basilisk sees its reflection within 30 feet of it in bright light, it mistakes itself for a rival and targets itself with its gaze.

info.name: Fusion or Fey?
desc: A harrowing mix between the greatest predatorial beast and the most furtive night stalker, the owlrex marries two fearsome foes into one. Bestial academics and seasoned hunters alike cannot identify the ancestry of the creature, partly due to the scarcity of viable specimen. No mating ritual has been witnessed, nor can their composition be directly traced to the Terren or Faerie realms. Because of how little is known, an owlrex found in the wild is a rarity and should be treated with care - and not just because of its ferocious nature. Bringing evidence of it to an historical researcher or arcane practitioner would certainly pique their interest. If an owlrex must be killed, a trophy from it would fetch an astoundingly steep price on the black market.

info.name: Woodland Scavengers.
desc: Unlike their ursine and saurian counterparts, owlrex are surprisingly shy. Preferring to pounce at night upon unaware prey, they must live in forested areas or land with enough cover to hide their large bodies. That said, owlrex tend to seek carrion rather than kill for meat. In a curiously intelligent way, they prefer easy food rather than a hunt, and will avoid a fight they deem too difficult. However discerning, don't mistake an owlrex's particularity as a trait fit for taming. A free meal may deter an owlrex from attacking, but its hunger will return along with its wild nature.

info.name: Nest Collectors.
desc: Any sizeable landmark an owlrex can jump atop of becomes its nest. This can sometimes be an outcropping of rock, a stout tree, or even an old tower. Using entire logs, an owlrex will assemble a roost the size of a large house to sleep within. The area for miles around an owlrex nest is devoid of sizeable fauna, since it has likely brought down any game it could eat, or any that rivaled it.

Once an owlrex's quarry has been worn down, it will incapacitate it and drag it back to its lair and store it in a decaying pile of flesh to feast on. This rotting hoard serves two purposes. One, for a steady food supply during colder seasons, and two, for the horrendous smell to keep away predators who travel too close. If one can recognize the smell of an owlrex nest, they can be easily tracked - that is, if the stench can be overcome.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A fight with an owlrex outside of its nest is fast and ferocious. Most likely, the owlrex will strike first as it hunts from the shadows. It will pick a feeble target to focus on and will not relent until it is worn down. After grappling the weakened target, it will use its wing attack to jump up and away 25 feet, then glide using the rest of its movement to escape with its meal back to its nest. If hurt or sufficiently frightened, an owlrex will readily flee in the same way with its wing attack, and may even drop its prey.

info.name: Glide.
desc: The owlrex has a fly speed where it glides. Gliding means a creature can fly, but it must end its turn at least 5 feet lower than where it began its flight, and cannot ascend during its flight.

name: Voodoo Coffin
resist: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine
senses: blindsight 60 ft., blind beyond this radius, passive Perception 8

effect.text: to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.
) necrotic damage. If the target is a Medium or smaller creature, it is grappled (escape

) and the coffin cannot grapple another target. Until this grapple ends, the target is restrained, blinded, cannot hear, and has total cover against all other creatures as it is dragged within the coffin.
At the beginning of each turn a target spends grappled inside the coffin, the target must make a
Constitution saving throw against poison, taking 7 (
) necrotic damage on a failed save, and half as much on a success. A creature dies if it is reduced to 0 hit points while grappled within the coffin and is considered consumed, immediately becoming a

The coffin opens its casket door and releases a 20-foot-radius noxious cloud of poison gas centered on itself. The cloud spreads around corners, and clings to the ground until the end of the coffin's next turn. The miasma-like cloud cannot be dispersed. Each creature that starts its turn within the cloud must make a
Constitution saving throw against poison. On a failed save, the creature takes 26 (

) poison damage and spends its action retching and reeling. A creature that succeeds on its saving throw takes half as much damage and does not lose its action. Creatures that don't need to breathe or are immune to poison suffer no consequences from this effect.
If this is the first time the Voodoo Coffin has used this ability today or since consuming a target with its pluck, a
steps out of the open casket, emerging into an unoccupied space within 5ft. of the coffin. The casket then closes.

info.name: Cursed Containers.
desc: The tether needed to raise a voodoo coffin lies not within a link between a necromancer and the corpse within, but with the necromancer and the coffin itself. A casket or other funerary burial container can be inscribed with runes of dark magics lost to all but those who pervert the ancient art of voodoo. While the underlying belief of voodooism embraces the spirits that journey between the land of the living and the dead, the twisted ritual that creates the enchanted coffin tears a hole between the two worlds in order to let the unliving energy spill forth.

It can sometimes take weeks to inscribe the obscene markings within the coffin, but once finished the magical engravings become invisible to the naked eye. Those that choose to create one may turn to grave robbing, otherwise more nefarious mages may curse a coffin before a burial takes place.

info.name: Unruly Subjects.
desc: Attempting to control a voodoo coffin is nearly impossible - it is far wiser to plan around its tendencies and let it run its wrathful course. Voodooism as a religion contacts one's spiritual ancestors for guidance, but the corruption of this sacred contract drives the souls beyond the veil mad with necromantic malevolence. Voodoo coffins seek out the descendants of the one who was buried within, or descendants of their predecessors. Once set on the trail of their targets, the voodoo coffin will not stop until it has devoured every last bit of its own bloodline. If a well-studied mage knows the burial place of their enemies forbearers, placing the voodoo curse on their coffin would create a ceaseless killer to hunt them to their end.

info.name: What's Inside?
desc: Though the coffin appears to be growing the enlarged limbs of its deceased contents, the testimony of those who have escaped from a coffin's clutches proves otherwise. Once pulled within the interior where the poisonous smog of decay pours from, the coughing and gagging subject may see the swirling void of ravenous souls beyond a portal where the bottom of the coffin once belonged. No body remains inside, only the infinite deathly darkness beyond and the spirits that clamor forth to claim another vessel. Even if a victim is able to wrench themselves from the ghostly hands lunging from the Shaderealms, the experience is enough to traumatize the soundest of minds into a state of insanity.

info.name: Combat.
desc: As described, a voodoo coffin will pinpoint its descendant with some otherworldly perception, as indicated by its blindsight. Anything that gets in its way might be a temporary meal, but the coffin won't stall for very long. Its approach is simple - repeatedly using its pluck to grapple its target inside its coffin body, and use its disgorge when it can to keep other interlopers away.

To the further dismay of adventurers, a party member killed inside makes the voodoo coffin stronger. It will immediately disgorge the victim and allow the mummy of their former friend to fight. After disgorging its bloodline relation, the coffin will retreat. It has no use for combat after eliminating their previous relative.

name: Clairvoyant
resist: psychic, radiant

effect.text: Uses of the Clairvoyant's per-round abilities return at the beginning of the Clairvoyant's turn.
When a creature the Clairvoyant can see makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, the Clairvoyant can choose to impose disadvantage on the roll, even after the initial result is rolled.
If disadvantaged, the Clairvoyant can choose to ignore the disadvantage for a single roll.

If the target is an object weighing 300 pounds or less that isn't being worn or carried, it is moved up to 30 feet in any direction. The fixator can also exert fine control on objects with this ray, such as manipulating a simple tool or opening a door or a container.

info.name: Obsessive Mind.
desc: One fixator's personality can differ wildly from another, but they always have a singular common purpose - an obsession with obtaining something of value to them. This can range from a powerful magic item, or the knowledge of a potent spell. Either way, fixators are not pleasant to encounter, but are much more affable than other eyestalkerkin. They may even have full conversations with other creatures, using their eye rays should the talks turn sour. But any topic they discuss is always to their own end in order to find and collect their chosen interest.

info.name: Evolutionary Insanity.
desc: A fixator is no danger to someone not interfering with its current objective. However, if left to their own devices, a fixator will at some point attain its goal. At that point, a fixator becomes increasingly dangerous. Its obsession does not stop - it only increases. It will do anything to hide its treasure from others, and does even more to protect it. Once it has what it always wanted, a fixator begins to think that everyone wants what it has. The longer a fixator harbors those thoughts, the more it reshapes its physical form to reflect its mental degradation. Slowly but surely, a fixator protecting its valuables becomes an eyestalker.

info.name: A Lack of Lairs.
desc: Fixators are always either searching for their objective, or actively working to protect it. Because of this, it is more common to encounter a fixator in the wild than it is to find a fixator's home. It's quite easy to track a fixator - they contain no regard for anything that is not the object of their desire, and therefore will raze an entire landscape in an effort to search or travel faster. However, that doesn't mean that a fixator is a wonton killer. They understand that creatures can be useful guides and will subjugate them to satisfy its demands.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A fixator prefers to float high above its enemies, throwing them against hard objects and disintegrating them little by little. It will try to remain at the maximum distance it can attack, since its antimagic focus extends as far as it can see.

A fixator has knowledge of spellcasting, and though unafraid of mages, it will actively prevent spells from being cast. When high level magic is about to be used, the fixator will refocus on the caster and stop the spell entirely. In other instances, particularly powerful attacks that land a hit with a magic weapon or a smite can also be negated when the fixator refocuses.

After dealing damage with this attack, the leechpod spawns two new leechpods in empty spaces within 10 ft., acting on their own initiative count. The original leechpod then dies.

info.name: Prolific Multiplier.
desc: None are quite sure where the first leechpod came from, but most everyone knows they are a terrible problem to have. Stories tell of towns where one was brought as an exotic specimen, only for the town to fall overnight - its residents becoming feed for the carnivorous plant.

Like a disease, one leechpod becomes two, two become four, and so on. An adventurer or creature caught off-guard by a leechpod serves not only as a meal, but also as a reproductive host. Even after undergoing their procreative fission, the results are not nascent sprouts. They are a fully grown duplicate of their original as soon as they have enough nutrients to split from their progenitor.

info.name: Dormant in Darkness.
desc: The Underrealms are the ideal habitat for the leechpod, following their tremorsense in the vast unlit caverns. Unfortunately, the scarcity of tasty humanoid blood can leave a leechpod unsatiated for weeks at a time. During those periods, leechpods have developed a form of hibernation where they retreat within their bulbs to preserve energy and hide from would-be predators. When they feel the presence of suitably sized prey walk nearby, the tendrils of the leechpod emerge forth. This can be a harrowing sight, as what appeared to be a copse of strange cabbage-like plants quickly grow mouthy tentacles and throw themselves at surprised adventurers.

info.name: Combat.
desc: It should be noted that leechpods are best used as a deterrent. Sneaking around a colony of them can be simple for stealthy individuals, but heavy-footed personnel would do best to steer away from a grove.

Leechpods alone are not fatal, but multiple leechpods in combat can very quickly lead to a death spiral. Use them sparingly. In an overwhelming encounter with leechpods, they will not stop splitting and forming new foes, so allow retreat as a viable option.
The very basis of a leechpod's lifespan relies on their expendability. They will throw themselves at creatures with no self preservation in order to replicate.

info.desc: Pomonids don't reproduce, nor do they have discernible gender. They do their best to live a healthy and good life, hoping to see a peaceful end of their days. When passing, other pominids will bury their bodies within lush groves. From the deceased grows a pominid tree, which after time bears fruit. The fruit matures into baby pominids, which fall to the ground by giving birth. Pominids believe that the number of pominids a pominid tree produces in their afterlife is determined by how many strangers the pominid helped during its lifetime. A pominid only lives an average of 50 years, and thus their desire to help others occasionally manifests as an overwhelming generosity.

The devil makes three melee attacks: two with its talons and one with its wings.

info.desc:
Less devil than a man cursed by devil magic, his arcane intelligence comes from his search for a cure. Though no cure existed, Slough found an arcane ritual to relieve his pain by inflicting pain upon others.

He himself can't heal, gaining hit points instead as a facsimile of skin that soon sheds away. His healing magic is a manipulation of the life force around him, rather than divine authority.

The cube's area is heavily obscured. It lasts for one minute or until a current disperses it.

The mother of the sea ignores difficult terrain, and magical effects can't reduce its speed or cause it to be restrained. It can spend 5 feet of movement to escape from nonmagical restraints or being grappled.
The mother of the sea makes two tentacle attacks, each of which it can replace with a barbed stinger attack.

The yen can spend a short rest eating a limb or body part of a humanoid creature. During its next long rest, the yen forms a cocoon. When it emerges, the yen's corresponding body part is replaced with an exact replica of the body part it had eaten.

The yen can also spend a short rest eating the brain of a spellcaster. After its next long rest, it learns a spell the spellcaster had prepared at their moment of death. The spell must be of a level for which it has spell slots, and it is always considered a prepared spell for the yen.

name: Dragon Tortoise
resist: thunder

effect.text: While the dragon tortoise remains motionless and half-buried, it is indistinguishable from a large boulder or hill.

The dragon tortoise has advantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws made against effects that would knock it prone or move it against its will. Additionally, if the dragon tortoise is moved against its will, the distance it is moved is halved. If the distance is 5 ft. or less, the dragon tortoise is not moved.
The dragon tortoise makes three attacks: one with its bite, one with its stomp, and one with its tail. They cannot be against the same target.

The dragon tortoise exhales a relaxing breath in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a

Constitution saving throw. On a failure, a creature becomes indifferent to the dragon tortoise until the end of its next turn. This indifference ends if the target is attacked or if it witnesses any of its friends being harmed by the dragon tortoise.

The dragon tortoise retreats within its shell. Until it takes a different action, it gains resistance to all damage except psychic damage. On the turn the dragon tortoise uses its withdrawal, it loses its walking speed and its burrow speed is reduced to 5 feet. If the dragon tortoise is half-buried or more when it takes this action, it regains 20 hit points and has advantage on all saving throws until it takes a different action.

info.name: boxtext
desc: The sand and dirt covering a nearby dune shifts as the hot sun reflects off moss encrusted scales. A head and neck unearth themselves and rear upwards, casting shadows and debris across those below. Large eyes blink and reflect an intelligent glint as enormous feet lift a timeworn and overgrown shell. With a swish and a shake of its serpentine tail, the dragon tortoise stands up to its full majestic height to greet the daylight sun.

info.name: Season Bringers.
desc: In their preferred element, a dragon tortoise keeps its shelled back comfortably warm and exposed, while it buries its head and limbs in the cool ground. When the stars shift and the weather changes, dragon tortoises uproot from their months-long slumber to find warmer climates.

This migratory pattern has given rise to folk tales of the dragon tortoise being responsible for the changing of the seasons. As the stories go, a dragon will gather the sunlight on its back and bring it along on its travels. Where it makes its rest, the sun will shine brightly for all who pay it homage.

info.name: Social Nesters.
desc: Unlike others of their kin, dragon tortoises sometimes gather in herds to commune and migrate together, but most will split off once they find a new home. Especially dry and sunny areas can be congregational spots for dragon tortoises on the move and can prove to be fruitful nesting grounds. None have ever seen a dragon tortoise eat nor do they speak of preying on a particular flora or fauna. Instead, the hypothesis is that dragon tortoises are photosynthetic, and bright expanses are necessary for successful reproduction.

info.name: Venerable Ancients.
desc: An astounding reverence is kept for dragon tortoises, known sometimes as hillwalker dragons. They are treated like gods of nature for their power and majesty, matched with their deep wisdom of the land before the mountains were born. Dragon tortoises live like an extension of the Terrenrealm they call home and can sense the changes it undergoes over the course of their indefinite lifetime, dying only when the land itself dies. The oldest dragon tortoises can detect when unnatural beings or extraplanar phenomena exist within the bordering miles, and will grant their knowledge to brave smallfolk as armaments against such threats.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A dragon tortoise is disinclined from fighting whatsoever. Attempting to damage it during its slumber will only prompt it to dig itself further underground until it is completely buried so its attackers lose interest. This behavior stems not from cowardice, but from the dragon's own experience that very few have the capacity to combat it. Were a dragon tortoise to unleash its full fury, few mortal creatures could bear it. The more pesky and relentless foes are turned back by its warming breath, which soothes the very soul. To truly fight a dragon tortoise, one must speak with it and have cause to challenge it to an honorable duel. Even then, the dragon will likely decline unless it feels its competitors are worthy of a challenge, and will not kill a creature lesser than itself.

In combat with many enemies, a dragon tortoise's bite can pull in ranged attackers, its stomp can flatten close combatants, and its tail can knock the wind out of the staunchest of defenders. These melee attacks may pack a punch, but the dragon tortoise is still very weak to spells and attacks made from long ranges. It deems such combat as dishonorable, and will have no hesitation in ending an unfair fight with its warming breath, or by retreating with its withdrawal and digging underground until its enemies draw close.

name: Flitterpuff
resist: bludgeoning, piercing, slashing
immune: bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from attacks not made with advantage

effect.text: After the flitterpuff is subjected to an attack roll, it moves 5 feet in a direction of its choosing. This movement does not provoke attacks of opportunity. If the flitterpuff's speed is 0, it loses this ability as well as its immunities.
Whenever the flitterpuff is subjected to lightning damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the lightning damage dealt.
The flitterpuff's innate spellcasting ability is Charisma (+4 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:
When a creature targets the flitterpuff with an attack or spell, it can release a cloud of its feathers. Each creature within 10 feet of the flitterpuff must succeed on a
Dexterity saving throw or become blinded until the end of the flitterpuff's next turn. Other flitterpuffs automatically succeed this saving throw.

info.name: Playful Pests.
desc: Floating in on a gentle breeze through the technicolor wilderness of the Faerierealms, flitterpuffs are adorable to the ignorant and annoying to the acquainted. They rely solely on the shifting winds to whisk them away on their travels, sometimes lingering for mere minutes, other times for days.

Friendly and seemingly harmless, it is tempting to befriend the fuzzy drifters. However, a large enough collection of flitterpuffs can blot out sunlight as they collect into a cloudy blanket, and their feathery shedding can drape over the earth like stubborn snow. All told, they are a nuisance to farmers, whose crops can suffer greatly if a colony does not blow away in time for harvest.

info.name: Surprisingly Shocking.
desc: The dry, cotton-like feathers of flitterpuffs can generate a latent field of static electricity. Curious investigators of flitterpuff swarms will find their hair standing on end and may experience a zap or two if they attempt to catch the critters. This electric energy is their lifeforce, and also how they hunt. By stunning tiny insects where they alight, flitterpuffs can render their meal helpless with a slight ruffle. When gathered in groups numbering in the hundreds, flitterpuffs dance in a revelry that can generate destructive static storms.

info.name: Combat.
desc: Fighting a flitterpuff is difficult, not only because of their evasive nature, but because it rarely fights back and will take flight into the wind. Its small size, fluffy nature, and playful attitude gives it an uncaring disposition regarding personal survival. A flitterpuff will approach any beast to befriend it, without holding grudges if the beast lashes out. After all, most creatures can do little to nothing to harm it since any attack creates drafts for it to ride out of reach. A flitterpuff's ability to waft away from enemies has conditioned it to soar merrily to safety rather than continuously engage something dangerous.

The Mutant Giant Spider has the same statistics as a

The hag magically polymorphs into a Small or Medium female humanoid, or back into its true form. Its statistics are the same in its humanoid and fey forms. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

info.name: A Gruesome Endowment.
desc: The path of a lone hag without a coven is a dreadful existence. A hag may have been cast out by her sisters, or her sisters may have perished at the hand of adventurers. Bickering amongst its members aside, a coven is a powerful tool to protect hags from outsiders, and to increase the power at their disposal. A hag without a coven can seek such power alone, but at the cost of the last shred of humanity left within them. The ritual to perform such a task is lost to mortal men, but desperate hags turn to deep texts to siphon the power of the oldest crones - the spider queens. The task is long and the pain endless, but their new bodies provide the potential to defend their home as an individual.

info.name: Dark Alterations.
desc: Once changed, a spider hag becomes less capricious and shrewd, devolving into an animalistic state of paranoia. Though they have achieved a greater force to arm themselves with, they constantly weave traps of web and poison around their abode. No amount of protection is ever enough for a spider hag. Their homely huts become a den of never-ending danger as they retreat into the deep recesses of their lair, using what was once a home as a death trap for visitors.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A spider hag won't fight if it can. It will rely on its traps, or will seek out weaker prey to use its bite attack against. If possible, the spider hag will target a sleeping creature with its bite. If it hits and the creature fails its saving throw, it stays unconscious while the hag carries it away to feast.

If forced to fight, a spider hag will always try to get the drop on its prey. That way, it can use its spider shape ability before any players get their turns. Its spider shape can absorb quite a bit of damage, but is quite weak. Once close to losing its spider shape, the hag will retreat and prefer to attack with its leg skewers, poison spit, and spells at range.

Though much more animalistic, a spider hag still has an acute sense of self-preservation, and will bargain to keep its own life. Any trinkets and baubles it once considered important when a normal hag, it will gladly trade to survive another day.

name: Vindsvalr, Lord of Unrelenting Ice

effect.text: Vindsvalr can create icy pillars beneath his feet, forming frozen stairs that move him upwards. For every 5 feet Vindsvalr walks, he can raise himself 5 feet upwards, so long as a creature does not occupy the space below. The pillars, which occupy a 5 by 5 foot space, grow to match the altitude of Vindsvalr's next step, becoming thinner at greater heights. Each pillar has AC 13, 40 hit points, vulnerability to fire damage and immunity to cold damage. Creatures within 5 feet of a pillar when it is destroyed must make a
Vindsvalr can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost him extra moment.
If Vindsvalr fails a saving throw, he can choose to succeed instead.

Spells with a casting time of 1 action also require expending a bonus action to use.
Potions freeze and cannot be imbibed.
A creature that falls unconscious in this area starts to freeze. It cannot regain hit points or become conscious until warmed.
Vindsvalr makes two sword attacks. He can replace one attack with a chill thrust.

The petrification lasts until the creature is freed by the greater restoration spell or other magic.

info.name: Wildborn.
desc: Forest giants are a species of giant-kin who do not descend from any lineage of true giants, nor are the spawn of a giant deity. When a revered beast of great power within a forest attains the blessing of a nature god or elder druid, they are elevated from their animal flesh into the form of a forest giant. Sometimes, when a forest is in great peril, this process will happen on its own, and a forest giant will be born unto the wilderness that has need of it.

The appearance of a forest giant reflects what beast it came from. Many have horns or antlers and are covered in fur, while others may have cloven feet or long tails. They are quite small as giants stand, reaching only 10 to 12 feet in height. They make no homes and hunt no game, preferring to eat leaves of the trees they can now reach. Forest giants have a keener intellect than what their animalistic nature suggests, using simple weapons and crafting materials to outfit themselves.

info.name: Shepherds and Caretakers.
desc: A forest giant always has a purpose that it was created for. Oftentimes, this sacred mission entails protecting a certain rare and magical creature and its herd from overly greedy hunters. It may also mean defending a certain sanctum within the forest from defilement, or preserving a plot of land where a unique and delicate plant grows.

Forest giants live for an indefinite period of time, but are aged and weary after 300 years. When their task is deemed complete by their creator, or they grow too old, they are returned to their bestial form to live out the remainder of their now mortal days, and another animal protector is raised to answer the call.

info.name: An Indifferent Selfishness.
desc: Outside of their realm, forest giants are willing to trade their harvests and crafts, and actively engage in teaching young species the ways of protecting nature. They can be a great boon to a community that supports the forest giant's cause. This is, however, at their own discretion, as their mission is beyond mortal comprehension and they may disappear for decades to focus on their appointed quest.

Inside their home turf, forest giants take a more apathetic approach and let nature run its course unless it directly interferes with their vocation. A traveler lost in the woods is unlikely to receive directions from a forest giant, as the giant may already foresee the traveler's demise in the jaws of wild beasts as an inevitable event. Unless one makes themselves useful to the giant, they may as well not exist.

info.name: Timber Seeds.
desc: A blessing all forest giants have is an unmatched green thumb. Plants they touch grow to maturity within minutes, and flourish beyond normal lifetimes. Forest giants can take advantage of this innate magic and use it as an offensive measure. While they prefer trees for their harmless nature, they can sprout any plant launched using the pouches they carefully craft and imbue with their druidic power.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A forest giant is wise enough to know that negotiation should always be the first option, but when push comes to shove it won't hesitate to use its immense strength. When interacting with humanoids or other intelligent creatures, a forest giant will always issue warnings before resorting to combat. It will fight to the death if it fears its sacred mission is at risk.

Forest giants are skilled in guerilla warfare, and the range granted by their strength makes them deadly snipers. It hides and attacks from afar, using timber seeds to knock down enemies. While their foe is off guard, a forest giant will relocate and continue firing from a distance. As a last resort to put distance between itself and its aggressors, a forest giant will use a timber seed beneath its feet and hold onto the tree as it grows, lifting itself into the air.

Whenever the swarm is subjected to lightning damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the lightning damage dealt, and its static discharge immediately recharges.

name: Fyrflame, Wildfire Walking
resist: bludgeoning, piercing

effect.text: A non-attack spell that specifically targets Fyrflame must first succeed a spell attack against it. If it fails, the spell cannot find its target and the action is wasted but the spell is not lost.
If Fyrflame fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

The area within a 5 foot radius of Fyrflame is constantly ablaze. The radius moves with Fyrflame, setting fire in an equally wide area behind it burns with the same effect until extinguished. The area is difficult terrain, and a creature takes 10 (

info.name: Militant Enforcers.
desc: Amidst the chaos of the Necrorealms, xylodynn are a force of will to whip the madness into a machine of war. Though not the most intelligent of its fiendish cousins, a xylodynn has unparalleled cunning in battle - so much so that demons of a greater order will reluctantly bow to listen to a xylodynn's command. A demon that usurps and devours those above itself with skill rather than brutal force may evolve into a xylodynn, or a demon lord may raise a commander to the rank of a xylodynn to exert greater control over their armies.

info.name: Infectious Barbarism.
desc: Xylodynn crave utter decimation of their foes in warfare, and are perfectly suited for it. While other demons prefer to corrupt and scheme in the Terrenrealms by subverting others to their will, a xylodynn seeks those who already have a thirst for blood and intensify it with hellish fury. Murderers and warmongers will likely find themselves tempted by a xylodynn's offers of power and tactical knowledge.

It is said that the mere presence of a xylodynn can lead an entire community to reverting to cruel tribal mentalities. Once their minds have unraveled, the xylodynn seizes control and quickly becomes their overlord, seen as an almost deistic figure that they zealously follow to war. Any that are crushed under the might of a xylodynn's army are subject to the same madness, and so its influence spreads like a disease of killing intent.

info.name: Spell Shunners.
desc: Xylodynn have an intriguing enmity towards spellcasters. Not only will they never approach one to offer their services, they will actively help any insurrection against one. In battle, should they hear spells being woven, they are overtaken by a raging impulse to silence the effect. This often leads to conflicts between xylodynn and other more wizardly commanders of demon armies, and even sometimes leads to rebellion against the demon lords who created them.

Some think that perhaps the xylodynn can hear the shrill sound of reality tearing as magic is summoned forth, and therefore fear and hate it. Alternate theories assert it stems from envy due to their own lack of spellcasting ability, while others hypothesize their scorn for arcane treachery comes from their own warped perspective of a fair fight.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A xylodynn seldom fights alone, and will issue orders to its underlings to have them fight much more tactically than a normal disorganized demon horde. Rather than sitting back and letting its lackeys fight for it, a xylodynn is more than willing to jump in and out of the thick of battle using its augmented flight. No military formation can stand against it as it pulls creatures away with its hook claws, then tosses them afar with its horn.

A xylodynn fights extremely optimally and makes very few mistakes when engaging in combat - that is, until it hears spellcasting. While its spell hatred reaction is quite strong, it can be used as a weakness against a xylodynn since they won't resist the urge to strike out at a mage. Baiting a xylodynn by casting spells is very easy, but the demon will likely become even angrier after being outsmarted. That anger might lead it to be more analytic in its decisions, or it may fly into a heated raging fury that could lead to even more slip-ups.

Though not cowardly, a xylodynn knows the importance of a retreat. When battles turn for the worse, a xylodynn will make haste to escape, plotting to return with a force strong enough to crush those who bested it.

info.name: boxtext
desc: Dear reader, since you are studying this, then either your interest has been piqued by such a high level entity, or you are searching for something challenging for a party nearing their capstones. Absolution can make an incredible friend or foe to such players, and will most certainly be of use to you. However, for the sake of your own settings and campaigns, any details of Absolution's deistic order and axioms are omitted, and no history is given. This is intentional, as presenting too many factual ties would inevitably overlap your own ideas of who Absolution could be. What is written below is instead a list of possible ways Absolution could be included in your campaign, with very little instruction shackling them to a single perspective. Let loose your creativity and read along for an inspirational journey.

info.name: A Party's Patron.
desc: Your players need a patron to oversee their deeds and reward them as adherents to a cause. Absolution can fill the role of one who watches over the party at all times, meddling only when needed and praising as often as they can. They may even chastise characters that stray from their path, and help guide them back to their righteous purpose.

When used this way, Absolution can either be an angelic presence sent by a greater deity, or a god in their own right. Insightful and perceptive characters may detect a warm and supportive presence around them as Absolution lingers invisibly nearby.

info.name: A Corrupted Idol.
desc: If your players are up to the challenge, Absolution can become a villain. Although tending towards good, all deities can fall from grace.

Perhaps the orchestration of sin was a divine conspiracy, with entities of the Netherrealms conducting the plot. In this scenario, Absolution would likely command the devils or demons in question, lending uncertainty to who is the puppet and who is the puppet master.

Perhaps Absolution drove themselves mad with obsession over perfection, considering mortals beyond saving and only worthy of annihilation. Absolution's power within the pantheon would still have standing, as they command legions of celestials to wipe away the Terrenrealms to begin anew on a clean slate.

info.name: A Draconic Emperor.
desc: Stronger than any of their ancient peers, Absolution could command the obedience of dragonkin. Consider making them the king of dragons, whose word is law even among the most chaotic of the deathspitters.

With this approach, Absolution could take a more neutral presence in your world. It may be that they sit among the stars in the heavens and are revered as the dragon god. Or they may even reside in the world itself, with dragons from across the land heeding Absolution's guidance.
Your players could plead Absolution to give aid to their allies and armies. If swayed, the draconic power at their command could change the tide of forthcoming battles.

info.name: An Ancestral Progenitor.
desc: If the descendants of celestials or dragonkin feature strongly in your world, consider an additional variant using Absolution's abilities. Any unifying features would likely include sparkling multicolor scales or pearly white and blue feathered wings.

Perhaps Absolution's children see them within the constellations, driving the heavens onwards with their sun and moon breath. Maybe they revel in combat superiority, adopting their inherited adaptability and raw strength.

info.name: Combat.
desc: Should your party come to blows with Absolution, it is imperative they come prepared. Absolution's ability to become invisible to any creatures at will is unrivaled. Even the strongest party who approaches Absolution without a plan to overcome the visibility problem will likely lose. This would require research before the fight, or a meeting with Absolution prior to combat could reveal the trait.

Futhermore, Absolution has their divine presence, an enhanced frightful presence action. It cannot be negated by immunity, nor does succeeding it once guarantee lifting the affliction. Armed with a modestly strong AC and an immense saving throw DC, Absolution will make quick work of a party that relies heavily on advantage for high rolls. Succeeding the initial saving throw or boosting a character's base Wisdom score can be crucial to winning the fight.

The splendor of the paragon trait is the pinnacle variant of an ability that all archangels have. This trait will undoubtedly slow down combat, but will increase the tension players feel. No matter how they approach Absolution, they may end up strengthening their foe.

Players will likely experience frustration fighting Absolution, as the godlike force before them will cause many good plans to fail. Absolution's legendary resistances, paired with their legendary might, makes them a formidably versatile and well equipped opponent even when its not their turn.

Coming prepared to resist radiant damage against Absolution is smart, but alternative breath weapons provide adaptability that is beyond player control. Absolution's sun breath is staggeringly powerful and able to be focused to even greater strengths at the cost of Absolution's legendary resistances. Their moon breath is much more like a standard dragon's breath weapon, but deals many types of damage to overwhelm resistant players.

Absolution is quick, hearty, and able to take more of a beating than their hit points suggest. When things are dire, Absolution will use their legendary actions to use their healing touch on themselves. This defensive strategy can be a signal to players that Absolution is on the ropes, and keeping up the offensive could soon lead to victory.

As a last additional note, if Absolution is still not up to par with the power level needed to challenge your players, consider that they are bipedal and have two free hands to wield whatever magic items you decide.

The bulu has advantage on saving throws against any spell that targets only the bulu (not an area). If the bulu's saving throw succeeds and the spell is of a level equal to or less than the bulu's current hit points, the spell has no effect on the bulu and instead targets the caster.

info.name: Angelic Omen.
desc: Sent by heavenly hosts to the Terrenrealms as guides for the souls of ancient beasts, the appearance of a bulu is a well-documented phenomenon among experienced rangers. Also called a snowfeather hare, bulu intercede between a hunter and their quarry, long enough for the prey to escape. It is both a beautiful and melancholy sight, as bulu are said to only appear to hunters who will very soon pass away. At the very least, it is common that a hunter who witnesses a bulu never hunts again.

The science behind this phenomenon is dubious. Bulu have been captured and studied, though with great difficulty. It has been discovered that a celestial protection enshrouds the creatures. Their innocence is so compelling that magic, space, time, and nature themselves bend around a bulu to protect it. The hare's absolute inability to cause harm is seen as the source of this heavenly blessing.

Philosophers hypothesize that hunters who cease their profession after viewing a bulu may be suffering from its celestial aftereffects, and can no longer willingly hurt an innocent creature. What cannot be proven, but has strong evidence supporting it, is the conclusion that harming a bulu does eventually bring about a terrible curse. After all, every critic that ensnares a bulu to curiously prod and provoke it meets their end in horrific fashion, or disappears entirely.

info.name: Deliciously Irresistable.
desc: Those who do not cower in the face of irrational tall tales and successfully slay a bulu report that its meat is incomparably delicious. So much so that men have been driven mad by its flavor, searching endlessly for its equal and endlessly failing.

For the demons and devils uncaring of curses, the taste of bulu is beyond a delicacy - it is an obsession. Denizens of lower planes have broken contracts just for a morsel, no matter how binding their word. If a bulu is presented as the sinful offering to extraplanar overlords, then equally potent, rare, and depraved the reward would be.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A bulu cannot fight, and will immediately flee upon hearing nearby enemies. When tasked by their angelic hosts, a bulu will intercept the attacks of foes by putting itself between an innocent creature and the attackers, but only long enough for the target to escape. Their only means of dealing damage are by turning spells back on their casters. All its other abilities in combat are meant to let a bulu fly to safety where it can heal at a rapid pace.

info.name: Warlock Familiar.
desc: With the DM's permission, a pact of the chain warlock who casts the find familiar spell can choose to conjure a bulu, so long as the patron is of a good alignment.

info.name: Symbiotic Adaptation.
desc: Mimics have been known to grow and change into deadly shapes, including doors, boats, and even houses. A kettle mimic is a mimic that has discovered a strange relationship with the environment around it. By turning into a container or receptacle of some sort, other substances find their way inside of a mimic. By adapting and overtaking that substance, a kettle mimic can exert a semblance of control over what is placed inside it.

info.name: A Useful Companion.
desc: With enough grooming, a kettle mimic can become a boon for spellcasters and adventurers. If their predatory nature is lost and the mimic is tamed, having a walking storage vessel is quite handy. A substance placed inside a kettle mimic decays at a much slower rate than normal, and hardly ever spills. In rare cases, a kettle mimic can even be commanded to attack and attempt to restrain oozes and elementals within itself. Unfortunately, the instinct of a mimic is hard to quell, and even with the tamest of mimics, a live creature places within one will likely find themselves being subject to the occasional bite.

info.name: Combat.
desc: A kettle mimic won't attempt to grapple foes as a surprise. With a certain amount of cunning, the mimic will wait for as many creatures to be within the radius of its boil over ability, then spring it as a surprise attack on unsuspecting foes. Afterwards, it will try to grapple as many creatures as possible while waiting to boil over once again.

The swarm summons a hail of fire. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius, 40-foot-high cylinder centered on a point within 80 feet must make a
Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 7 (

) force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. The cylinder remains until the start of the swarm's next turn. A creature that ends its turn in the cylinder is subject to its effects.
The swarm shoots crimson lightning in a line 60 feet long and 5 feet wide. Each creature in the line must make a
Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 13 (

) necrotic damage, or half as much on a successful one. Creatures that fail their saving throw have their maximum hit points reduced by the amount of necrotic damage taken until their next short or long rest.

info.name: boxtext
desc: An especially cunning spellcaster weaves an enchanted trap upon his prized possessions. A set of cursed armor levitates towards greedy adventurers. The ghost of a dead hero rises and takes hold of its legendary weapons to roam once again.

info.name: Living Loot.
desc: However a swarm of hostile magic items is conjured, its animate whirling malice magnifies the intensity of the sorcery within. Creating this perilous construct isn't easy, and keeping it from wonton destruction is just as hard. The simplest way to utilize the swarm's power is to keep it sealed alongside whatever needs protecting, so that whoever stumbles inside is unaware of the nasty surprise locked within. A more skilled arcane practitioner can make use of the swarm's antimagic susceptibility by creating an antimagic area within the swarm. When unwanted visitors trigger a trap, the antimagic is dispelled, and the swarm springs to life.

info.name: Minimal Magic Control.
desc: The swarm is not living, and cannot control magic items as well as an intelligent creature. It can amplify the destructive aspect of items, but has negligible fine control over nuanced operations. With this in mind, a swarm can contain any items of varying abilities and potency, but manifests them in ways similar to what is listed.

A swarm also need not true enchanted items. Nonmagical items used in the same summoning ritual will yield magical properties whilst the swarm survives, though the cost of raw components is much greater to the caster. Conjuration experts can even produce the items from thin air. That way, when a conjured swarm is defeated, the mage loses no personal belongings as the items dissolve into smoky ashen heaps.

info.name: Combat.
desc: The uncontrollable anarchic behavior of the swarm is reflected by its lack of optimal item utilization. Every turn (not round), the swarm becomes a significantly different creature. Sometimes the swarm will be as deadly as an archmage, and other times it will fare no better than a fledgling soldier. The swarm is aggressive towards anyone other than its creator and their designated allies, and has no mortal fear considering its constructed anatomy. Therefore, it is best for the swarm to carelessly wade into combat to best make use of any of its fluctuating abilities at any time.

name: Animated Training Dummy
immune: poison, psychic; bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing from nonmagical attacks
immunity: blinded, charmed, deafened, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned, unconscious
languages: understands the languages of its creator but can't speak

effect.text: When a training dummy becomes animated, it has two of the below properties. If no weapon property is chosen, the training dummy wields a club and deals bludgeoning damage with its weapon attack. During a short rest, the training dummy can swap one property for another, provided with the proper equipment:
Gain a multiattack of two weapon attacks. Cannot be used with spear.
Gain weapon reach of 10 feet and deal an additional die of weapon damage.
Gain advantage on saving throws against magical effects.
Strength based attacks against the dummy have disadvantage.
Dexterity based attacks against the dummy have disadvantage.
While the training dummy remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal training dummy.
While prone, the training dummy is considered restrained and cannot stand up of its own accord.
to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.
If a creature starts its turn within 30 feet of the basilisk and the two of them can see each other, the basilisk can force the creature to make a

Constitution saving throw if the basilisk isn't incapacitated. On a failed save, the creature magically begins to turn to stone and is restrained. It must repeat the saving throw at the end of its next turn. On a success, the effect ends. On a failure, the creature is petrified until freed by the

A creature that isn't surprised can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If it does so, it can't see the basilisk until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If it looks at the basilisk in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.
A basilisk tyrant is immune to the gaze of basilisks, and will not mistake its reflection as a rival.
If a creature misses the basilisk with a melee attack roll on its turn, it takes 3 (
) piercing damage at the end of its turn.
to hit, reach 5 ft., one target.
) poison damage, and the creature is coated in basilisk saliva. Until the creature takes an action to wipe off the saliva, it has disadvantage on all ability checks.

legendary.info: The basilisk can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The basilisk regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

effect.text: The basilisk makes one bite attack.

The basilisk shakes a shower of spines off its body, which coat the ground within a 30 foot radius centered on itself. The area becomes difficult terrain. When a creature moves into or within the area, it takes
piercing damage for every 5 feet it travels. Basilisks are not affected by the spines. A 5 foot square of the spines can be cleared away as an action.

The spines of a basilisk tyrant are crystalline and reflective, making it difficult to avoid the basilisk's gaze. A creature the basilisk can see within a space affected by the basilisk's spine shake must make a
Wisdom saving throw. On a failure, the creature cannot avert its gaze on its next turn.
